notes: Clusters ~100 variants under ~20 roots. Keep roots aligned to Matrix Principles; use drivers for context weighting.

root.label: Strawman
root.definition: Misrepresenting an opponent’s position to make it easier to attack.

variants.label: Classic Strawman
variants.definition: Substitute a distorted version of the claim, then refute that instead.
examples: She says we should invest in QA; apparently she wants to waste money testing every tiny thing.

heuristics: Claim paraphrase + intensifier words; mismatched modality vs original

variants.label: Hollow Man
variants.definition: Invent a weak opposing view no one stated, then defeat it.
examples: Some people think metrics are useless; clearly we shouldn’t track anything.

root.label: Ad Hominem
root.definition: Attack the person rather than the argument.

variants.label: Abusive Ad Hominem
variants.definition: Direct insult as a substitute for a reasoned response.
examples: Your idea is dumb; next.

heuristics: Second-person attack + absence of claim engagement

variants.label: Tu Quoque
variants.definition: Dismiss a claim because the speaker is inconsistent.
examples: You missed a deadline last month, so your scheduling plan is worthless.

heuristics: Shift from claim merits → speaker behavior mismatch

root.label: Post Hoc
root.definition: Assuming causation because B followed A.

variants.label: Post hoc ergo propter hoc
variants.definition: Temporal order mistaken for causal link.
examples: We launched the blog then sales rose; the blog caused the lift.

heuristics: Temporal connector + causal verb with no control comparison

root.label: False Dichotomy
root.definition: Presenting two options as the only possibilities.

variants.label: Either–Or
variants.definition: Forcing a binary choice when more options exist.
examples: Either we pivot now or we die.

root.label: Slippery Slope
root.definition: Arguing that a minor step will inevitably lead to a chain of disastrous outcomes.

variants.label: Domino Fallacy
variants.definition: Claiming one event will trigger many others without causal support.
examples: If we hire one remote worker, soon everyone will stop coming to the office.

root.label: Confirmation Bias
root.definition: Focusing on evidence that supports your belief and ignoring contradictory data.

variants.label: Cherry Picking
variants.definition: Highlighting only examples that confirm your position.
examples: Our three happy clients prove this approach always works.

root.label: Appeal to Authority
root.definition: Arguing that a claim must be true because an authority believes it.

variants.label: Irrelevant Authority
variants.definition: Using an expert in one area as authority in another.
examples: A celebrity investor says AI is safe, so it must be.

root.label: Appeal to Ignorance
root.definition: Claiming something is true because it hasn’t been proven false.

variants.label: Argument from Silence
variants.definition: Treating lack of evidence as evidence of lack.
examples: No one has disproved it, so it must be real.

root.label: Bandwagon
root.definition: Assuming something is correct because it’s popular.

variants.label: Appeal to Popularity
variants.definition: Popularity mistaken for truth.
examples: Everyone’s using it, so it must be best.

root.label: Red Herring
root.definition: Diverting attention from the real issue to a different topic.

variants.label: Topic Shift
variants.definition: Raising a side issue to distract from the main point.
examples: Why discuss safety when others have bigger problems?

root.label: Circular Reasoning
root.definition: Using the conclusion as a premise without justification.

variants.label: Begging the Question
variants.definition: The claim assumes its own truth.
examples: We know he’s honest because he always tells the truth.

root.label: Composition / Division
root.definition: Assuming what’s true of parts must be true of the whole, or vice versa.

variants.label: Part-to-Whole
variants.definition: Attributes of members assumed for the group.
examples: Each engineer is great, so the team will succeed.

root.label: Anecdotal Fallacy
root.definition: Using personal stories instead of data as proof.

variants.label: Vivid Anecdote
variants.definition: One personal example used to reject general data.
examples: My uncle smoked all his life and lived to 90.

root.label: Ambiguity
root.definition: Misleading by using double meanings or unclear language.

variants.label: Equivocation
variants.definition: Using a key term in two different senses.
examples: Freedom means never being told what to do.

root.label: Loaded Question
root.definition: Asking a question that presupposes guilt or bias.

variants.label: Complex Question
variants.definition: Smuggles an assumption within the question itself.
examples: When did you stop avoiding responsibility?

root.label: Hasty Generalization
root.definition: Drawing a broad conclusion from limited cases.

variants.label: Small Sample Bias
variants.definition: Too few examples used to represent the whole.
examples: Two customers complained, so everyone hates it.

root.label: Appeal to Emotion
root.definition: Manipulating emotions instead of evidence.

variants.label: Appeal to Fear
variants.definition: Arguing through threats or worst-case imagery.
examples: If we don’t act now, everything will collapse.

root.label: Sunk Cost Fallacy
root.definition: Continuing an endeavor because of past investment, not current value.

variants.label: Escalation of Commitment
variants.definition: Doubling down to justify prior effort.
examples: We’ve spent too much to quit now.

root.label: Naturalistic Fallacy
root.definition: Assuming what is natural is inherently good.

variants.label: Appeal to Nature
variants.definition: ‘Natural’ used as synonym for ‘right’.
examples: It’s natural to compete, so it’s fine to undercut others.

root.label: False Equivalence
root.definition: Treating two things as morally or logically the same despite relevant differences.

variants.label: Superficial Similarity
variants.definition: Equating items that share a surface trait but differ on decisive factors.
examples: Both are subscriptions, so canceling either has the same impact.

root.label: No True Scotsman
root.definition: Protecting a universal claim by redefining membership of a group.

variants.label: Retreat to Purity
variants.definition: Excluding counterexamples by narrowing the group after the fact.
examples: Real innovators don’t worry about safety metrics.

root.label: Genetic Fallacy
root.definition: Judging a claim as true/false solely because of its origin.

variants.label: Source Dismissal
variants.definition: Rejecting the claim because of who/where it came from.
examples: That idea started on Twitter, so it’s not serious.

root.label: Appeal to Tradition
root.definition: Claiming something is right because it’s old or customary.

variants.label: We’ve Always Done It
variants.definition: Endorsing a practice solely due to longevity.
examples: We can’t change the process; it’s how we’ve always done it.

root.label: Appeal to Novelty
root.definition: Claiming something is better because it’s new.

variants.label: Newness = Better
variants.definition: Assuming recency implies superiority.
examples: The newest framework is obviously the best.

root.label: Texas Sharpshooter
root.definition: Finding patterns after the fact and mistaking them for intent or signal.

variants.label: Cluster Illusion
variants.definition: Draw the target after seeing the hits.
examples: We won 3 deals in healthcare—clearly we’re a healthcare company now.

root.label: Survivorship Bias
root.definition: Focusing on winners and ignoring the many unseen failures.

variants.label: Only Winners Count
variants.definition: Using visible successes as proof of ease or correctness.
examples: Founders who dropped out became billionaires—college is useless.

root.label: Base Rate Neglect
root.definition: Ignoring prior probabilities when interpreting evidence.

variants.label: Prior Blindness
variants.definition: Overweighting a specific test or anecdote vs population stats.
examples: The test is 95% accurate, so the positive must mean we have it.

root.label: Gambler’s Fallacy
root.definition: Believing future probabilities are altered by past random events.

variants.label: Due for a Win
variants.definition: Expecting reversal after a streak.
examples: We’ve had 5 losses—surely we’re due to win now.

root.label: Appeal to Consequences
root.definition: Arguing a claim is true/false because the outcome would be desirable/undesirable.

variants.label: Wishful Proof
variants.definition: Using desirability/undesirability as proof.
examples: If AI bias were real, we’d have to pause development—so it’s exaggerated.

root.label: Middle Ground
root.definition: Assuming the compromise between two positions must be correct.

variants.label: Compromise = Truth
variants.definition: Treating the midpoint as inherently valid.
examples: Let’s split the difference—then it’s fair and correct.
